title: Classic Board Games
description: Test your knowledge of beloved board games — from Monopoly to Trivial Pursuit and beyond!

questions.question: In Monopoly, how much money does each player start with?
questions.explanation: Each Monopoly player starts with $1,500, divided into denominations of $500, $100, $50, $20, $10, $5, and $1 bills.

questions.question: In the game Clue (Cluedo), which room is in the center of the board?
questions.explanation: The Cellar is in the center of the classic Clue board. Players cannot enter it during normal gameplay — it's used for the envelope holding the solution cards.

questions.question: How many letter tiles are there in a standard English Scrabble set?
questions.explanation: A standard Scrabble set contains exactly 100 letter tiles, including 2 blank tiles that can represent any letter.

questions.question: What year was the board game Risk first released?
questions.explanation: Risk was first published in 1957 in France under the name 'La Conquête du Monde' (The Conquest of the World) by director Albert Lamorisse.

questions.question: In chess, which piece can only move diagonally?
questions.explanation: The bishop is the only chess piece restricted to diagonal movement. Each player starts with two bishops — one on light squares and one on dark squares.

questions.question: What color are the properties in the most expensive group on a standard US Monopoly board?
questions.explanation: The most expensive properties on the standard US Monopoly board are Park Place and Boardwalk, which belong to the dark blue color group.

questions.question: Trivial Pursuit was invented in which country?
questions.explanation: Trivial Pursuit was invented in December 1979 by Canadian journalists Chris Haney and Scott Abbott in Montreal, Quebec.

questions.question: In the game of Life, what do players spin to move?
questions.explanation: The Game of Life uses a numbered wheel (spinner) instead of dice. Players flick the spinner and move that number of spaces along the track.

questions.question: Which classic game involves removing wooden blocks from a tower without toppling it?
questions.explanation: Jenga, created by Leslie Scott and first sold in 1983, challenges players to remove one wooden block at a time from a stacked tower without making it fall.

questions.question: What is the highest-scoring letter tile in Scrabble?
options: Both Q and Z (10 points each)
questions.explanation: Both Q and Z are worth 10 points each in Scrabble, making them the highest-scoring individual letter tiles in the game.

questions.question: In Candy Land, what is the name of the final destination on the board?
questions.explanation: Players race to reach King Kandy's Candy Castle at the end of the rainbow trail in this classic children's board game, first published in 1949.

questions.question: How many suspects are there in the original version of Clue?
questions.explanation: The original Clue has 6 suspects: Miss Scarlet, Colonel Mustard, Mrs. White, Mr. Green, Mrs. Peacock, and Professor Plum.

questions.question: In checkers (draughts), what happens when a piece reaches the opposite end of the board?
options: The player gets an extra turn
questions.explanation: When a checker piece reaches the far end of the board, it is 'kinged' — a captured piece is stacked on top, and it gains the ability to move backward.

questions.question: What classic board game was first sold by Parker Brothers in 1935 during the Great Depression?
questions.explanation: Monopoly was first published by Parker Brothers in 1935. Despite the economic hardship of the Depression, the game about buying property became an instant bestseller.

questions.question: In Battleship, what is the largest ship on the board?
questions.explanation: The Aircraft Carrier is the largest ship in Battleship, taking up 5 holes on the grid. The other ships are the Battleship (4), Submarine (3), Destroyer (3), and Patrol Boat (2).

questions.question: What board game challenges players to describe a word without saying certain 'taboo' words?
questions.explanation: Taboo, published by Hasbro in 1989, gives players a word to describe while listing several related 'taboo' words they cannot say. A buzzer is sounded for violations.

questions.question: In the original game of Operation, what is the patient's name?
questions.explanation: The patient in Operation is named 'Cavity Sam.' Players use tweezers to remove funny ailments like a 'broken heart' and 'butterflies in stomach' without touching the edges.

questions.question: How many colored categories are in Trivial Pursuit?
questions.explanation: Trivial Pursuit features 6 categories: Geography (blue), Entertainment (pink), History (yellow), Art & Literature (brown), Science & Nature (green), and Sports & Leisure (orange).

questions.question: Which game involves flipping small plastic discs into a cup?
questions.explanation: Tiddlywinks is a classic game where players use a larger disc (the 'squidger') to flip smaller plastic discs ('winks') into a cup in the center of a mat.

questions.question: In Connect Four, how many pieces in a row do you need to win?
questions.explanation: As the name suggests, you need four pieces in a row — horizontally, vertically, or diagonally — to win Connect Four, first sold by Milton Bradley in 1974.
